xxl.core.cursors.distincts
Class SortBasedDistinct<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      xxl.core.cursors.distincts.SortBasedDistinct<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
Direct Known Subclasses:
SortBasedDistinct
public class SortBasedDistinct<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>

A sort-based implementation of a distinct operator, i.e., all duplicates contained in the input cursor will be removed. The input cursor is traversed and a predicate determines whether two successive input elements are equal. If this is the case the duplicates will not be returned by calls to next or peek.

Note: This operator can be used with a sorted or unsorted input cursor! If the input cursor is not sorted a new merge sorter will be created using distinct queues for an early duplicate elimination. Therefore this operator only forwards the method calls to the merge sorter. If an input iteration is given by an object of the class Iterator, i.e., it does not support the peek operation, it is internally wrapped to a cursor.

Example usage (1): 

   SortBasedDistinct<Integer> distinct = new SortBasedDistinct<Integer>(
       new ArrayCursor<Integer>(
           new Integer[] {1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 4, 5, 6}
       )
   );
   
   distinct.open();
   
   while (distinct.hasNext())
       System.out.println(distinct.next());
   
   distinct.close();
The input cursor contains the elements {1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 4, 5, 6}. If the sort-based distinct operation is applied all duplicates will be removed, i.e., each delivered element returned by call to next is unique. This example uses the equal predicate by default, therefore two elements are compared according to their integer values. If the sort-based distinct operator is completely consumed, the output of this example looks as follows: 
   1
   2
   3
   4
   5
   6

Example usage (2): early duplicate elimination 

   distinct = new SortBasedDistinct<Integer>(
       new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(10), 20),
       ComparableComparator.INTEGER_COMPARATOR,
       8,
       12*4096,
       4*4096
   );
   
   distinct.open();
   
   while (distinct.hasNext())
       System.out.println(distinct.next());
   
   distinct.close();
This example sorts twenty randomly distributed integer values of the interval [0, 10) and removes all duplicates using distinct queues to store the elements during run-creation.

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, Queue, DistinctQueue, NestedLoopsDistinct, SortBasedDistinct

SortBasedDistinct

public SortBasedDistinct(java.util.Iterator<? extends E> input,
                         java.util.Comparator<? super E> comparator,
                         int blockSize,
                         int objectSize,
                         int memSize,
                         double firstOutputBufferRatio,
                         double outputBufferRatio,
                         double inputBufferRatio,
                         int finalMemSize,
                         double finalInputBufferRatio,
                         Function<java.lang.Object,? extends Queue<Cursor<E>>> newQueuesQueue,
                         java.util.Comparator<? super Cursor<E>> queuesQueueComparator)
Creates a new sort-based distinct operator and sorts the input at first using a merge sorter with distinct queues. The merge sorter performs an early duplicate elimination during the sort operation.

Parameters:
input - the input iterator to be sorted.
comparator - the comparator used to compare the elements in the heap (replacement selection).
blockSize - the size of a block (page).
objectSize - the size of an object in main memory.
memSize - the memory available to the merge sorter during the open-phase.
firstOutputBufferRatio - the ratio of memory available to the output buffer during run-creation (0.0: use only one page for the output buffer and what remains is used for the heap; 1.0: use as much memory as possible for the output buffer).
outputBufferRatio - the amount of memory available to the output buffer during intermediate merges (not the final merge) (0.0: use only one page for the output buffer, what remains is used for the merger and the input buffer, inputBufferRatio determines how the remaining memory is distributed between them; 1.0: use as much memory as possible for the output buffer).
inputBufferRatio - the amount of memory available to the input buffer during intermediate merges (not the final merge) (0.0: use only one page for the input buffer, what remains is used for the merger (maximal FanIn); 1.0: use as much memory as possible for the input buffer).
finalMemSize - the memory available to the merge sorter during the next-phase.
finalInputBufferRatio - the amount of memory available to the input buffer of the final (online) merge (0.0: use the maximum number of inputs (maximal fanIn), i.e., perform the online merge as early as possible; 1.0: write the entire data into a final queue, the online "merger" just reads the data from this queue).
newQueuesQueue - if this function is invoked, the queue, that should contain the queues to be merged, is returned. The function takes an iterator and the comparator queuesQueueComparator as parameters, e.g., 
          new Function<Object, Queue<E>>() {
              public Queue<E> invoke(Object iterator, Object comparator) {
                  return new DynamicHeap<E>((Iterator<E>)iterator, (Comparator<E>)comparator);
              }
          };
The queues contained in the iterator are inserted in the dynamic heap using the given comparator for comparison.
queuesQueueComparator - this comparator determines the next queue used for merging.
See Also:
MergeSorter

SortBasedDistinct

public SortBasedDistinct(java.util.Iterator<? extends E> input,
                         java.util.Comparator<? super E> comparator,
                         int objectSize,
                         int memSize,

Creates a new sort-based distinct operator and sorts the input at first using a merge sorter with distinct queues. The merge sorter performs an early duplicate elimination during the sort operation.

Parameters:
input - the input iterator to be sorted.
comparator - the comparator used to compare the elements in the heap (replacement selection).
objectSize - the size of an object in main memory.
memSize - the memory available to the merge sorter during the open-phase.
finalMemSize - the memory available to the merge sorter during the next-phase.
See Also:
MergeSorter
Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the sort-based distinct operator, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open the input iteration, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor<E>

close

public void close()
Closes the sort-based distinct operator. Signals the cursor to clean up resources, close the input cursor, etc. After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the sort-based distinct operator remains in the state "closed".

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor<E>

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

The first element can instantly be returned, after that the operator remains in the state initialized. If a further element exists it is checked by the given predicate invoked on the last and the next element of the input cursor. If the predicate returns true this next element is filtered out, otherwise it will be returned by a call to next.

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the sort-based distinct operator has more elements.

nextObject

protected E nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be removed from the iteration, if next is called. This method returns the next element of the input cursor, which has not been filtered out by the given predicate.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

remove

public void remove()
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                   java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying data structure the last element returned by the sort-based distinct operator (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek. The behaviour of a sort-based distinct operator is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

Specified by:
remove in interface java.util.Iterator<E>
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
remove in class AbstractCursor<E>
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the sort-based distinct operator, i.e., the underlying cursor does not support the remove operation.

supportsRemove

public boolean supportsRemove()
Returns true if the remove operation is supported by the sort-based distinct operator. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsRemove in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
supportsRemove in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the remove operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

update

public void update(E object)
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                   java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Replaces the object that was returned by the last call to next or peek (optional operation). This operation must not be called after a call to hasNext. It should follow a call to next or peek. This method should be called only once per call to next or peek. The behaviour of a sort-based distinct operator is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

Specified by:
update in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
update in class AbstractCursor<E>
Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the object returned by the last call to next or peek.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if there is no object which can be updated.
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the SortBasedDistinct operator, i.e., the underlying cursor does not support the update operation.

supportsUpdate

Returns true if the update operation is supported by the sort-based distinct operator. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:

Overrides:

reset

public void reset()
           throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the sort-based distinct operator to its initial state (optional operation). So the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again. The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<E>
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by the sort-based distinct operator.
